title: Reading an old Finnish folk tale out loud! The Boy and The Goblin  |  Learn Finnish
content: Tällä kertaa mää kokeilen jotain vähän erilaista. This time, I’ll try something a little different. Mää nimittäin löysin mun vanhempien kotoa tällaisen vanhan suomalaisen satukirjan. That is, I found from my parents’ home this old Finnish storybook. Mää aion nyt lukea yhden sadun ääneen. I’m going to read one of the stories out loud. Videossa on englanninkieliset tekstitykset, mutta ei suomenkielisiä, koska teksti näkyy kuvassa. The video has English subtitles but not Finnish (during the story), because the text is shown on screen. Nämä on kansansatuja, jotka on toimittanu ja muokannu Iivo Härkönen. These are folk tales that have been edited and reworked by Iivo Härkönen. Kuvitukset puolestaan on Rudolf Koivun ja Onni Muusaaren käsialaa. The illustrations in turn are by Rudolf Koivu and Onni Muusaari. Tässä sadussa, jonka mää seuraavaksi luen, on Rudolf Koivun kuvitukset. The story that I’m about to read has Rudolf Koivu’s illustrations. Tarina menee näin: The story goes like this: The boy and the goblin Once a small boy was traveling the world and he only had 3 loaves in his birch bark container. He met an old man who asked him for alms. “Well, I myself don’t have more than 3 loaves in my container, but I’ll give you one of them, I’ll still have two left,” said the boy and gave the man a loaf. “Well, since you are such a good boy, I will give you this bag, this old worn out bag,  that maybe you can do something with. You could perhaps put those loaves into it and discard the birch bark container. When loaves run out or you in some other way are in trouble, just say ‘indeed, I do have this bag!’, and maybe you’ll get some help.” The boy took the gift, thanked the man and strolled along. When he had been walking for 3 days, the loaves ran out and he got hungry. He sat down on a rock and thought, what could he do next. Then he remembered the advice he got from the old man and said: “Indeed, I do have that bag!” At that moment, from a large swarm of geese flying above, two big geese flied into his bag. One of them he kept in the bag, but the other one he roasted and ate. That night he arrived at a house. He was very tired and wanted to get in to spend the night. He knocked on the gate, but the gate wasn’t opened. That's when he remembered the goose that was still in his bag, and uttered: “Do let me in, you’ll get a goose as a reward!” “We would let you in,” said the farmer, “but the only room available is the old cottage, and it is visited by the goblin every night.” “I will cope with that!” “Well, if you do, go ahead and come in!” The boy went in and settled in the old cottage for the night. At midnight, the goblin came in the cottage. “Ahha, there’s a guest here,” it said. “Sure there is,” said the boy bravely. “Well, aren’t you rather loud! You don’t seem to even know who I am.” “And you don’t seem to know who I am,” the boy replied. “This is my cottage!” “This is my accommodation!” “Which one of us shall leave?” “We'll see!” The troll attacked the boy and a fight ensued. They wrestled on, and soon the boy was almost defeated. But then he remembered his bag and said: “Indeed, I do have that bag!” Instantly, the bag opened, expanded more and more, and soon the goblin was inside it and the mouth of the bag closed. And it wouldn’t open. When the goblin saw that he couldn’t get anywhere, he became very humble and started to beg the boy for mercy. “What will you give me if I let you out?” “I’ll leave this house forever.” “I’m not settling for that.” “I’ll give you a wiper, and whenever you touch any sore spot with it, it’ll instantly heal.” “I’m not settling for that, either.” “I’ll give you such a seat that whoever sits on it, shall never be able to get out.” “Well, if you fulfill all these promises and also move to a small island to live in for the rest of your life, I’ll let you out of the bag.” “But you must also promise that you’ll never enter that island to disturb me, or if you do, I’ll get to eat you.” “Agreed!” So the matters were settled and the boy let the goblin off the hook. Following the promise he had made, the goblin escaped to his small island, but the boy stayed to live in the world. With his miraculous objects he gained lots of success. With the wiper, he healed the ill, with the stool and the bag he performed funny tricks and jokes. Once in his later years he happened to be rowing in the sea where the goblin had his refuge. The wind drove him to the island shore. He suspected nothing and made a fire on the beach to get warm and to cook a meal for himself. At that moment, the goblin came. “Ahha, you did not remember your promise, you came to my island,” it snapped. “So it would seem.” “Well, now you came to such a place that you won’t leave alive! I’ll eat you!” “Don’t eat me just yet, but wait until I first cook this soup and eat it. I’ll then be a better meal for you. Sit on my stool in the meantime!” The goblin didn’t remember the secret of the stool, so he sat down. But he couldn’t leave the seat, so he remained seating in his spot. He had to just watch how the man began to row out of the island. Sen pituinen se. That's all there is to tell.

They wrestled on, and soon the boy was almost defeated.
But then he remembered his bag and said: “Indeed, I do have that bag!” Instantly, the bag opened, expanded more and more, and soon the goblin was inside it and the mouth of the bag closed.
And it wouldn’t open.
When the goblin saw that he couldn’t get anywhere, he became very humble and started to beg the boy for mercy.

“What will you give me if I let you out?” “I’ll leave this house forever.” “I’m not settling for that.” “I’ll give you a wiper, and whenever you touch any sore spot with it, it’ll instantly heal.” “I’m not settling for that, either.” “I’ll give you such a seat that whoever sits on it, shall never be able to get out.” “Well, if you fulfill all these promises and also move to a small island to live in for the rest of your life, I’ll let you out of the bag.” “But you must also promise that you’ll never enter that island to disturb me, or if you do, I’ll get to eat you.” “Agreed!” So the matters were settled and the boy let the goblin off the hook.

With his miraculous objects he gained lots of success.
With the wiper, he healed the ill, with the stool and the bag he performed funny tricks and jokes.
Once in his later years he happened to be rowing in the sea where the goblin had his refuge.
The wind drove him to the island shore.
He suspected nothing and made a fire on the beach to get warm and to cook a meal for himself.
At that moment, the goblin came.
“Ahha, you did not remember your promise, you came to my island,” it snapped.
“So it would seem.” “Well, now you came to such a place that you won’t leave alive!
I’ll eat you!” “Don’t eat me just yet, but wait until I first cook this soup and eat it.
I’ll then be a better meal for you.
Sit on my stool in the meantime!” The goblin didn’t remember the secret of the stool, so he sat down.
But he couldn’t leave the seat, so he remained seating in his spot.
He had to just watch how the man began to row out of the island.

That's all there is to tell.

Then he remembered the advice he got from the old man and said: “Indeed, I do have that bag!”

“Ahha, there’s a guest here,” it said.

The troll attacked the boy and a fight ensued.
They wrestled on, and soon the boy was almost defeated.
But then he remembered his bag and said: “Indeed, I do have that bag!”
Instantly, the bag opened, expanded more and more, and soon the goblin was inside it and the mouth of the bag closed.

“What will you give me if I let you out?” “I’ll leave this house forever.”

With the wiper, he healed the ill, with the stool and the bag he performed funny tricks and jokes.
Once in his later years he happened to be rowing in the sea where the goblin had his refuge.
The wind drove him to the island shore.
He suspected nothing and made a fire on the beach to get warm and to cook a meal for himself.
At that moment, the goblin came. “Ahha, you did not remember your promise, you came to my island,” it snapped.
“So it would seem.” “Well, now you came to such a place that you won’t leave alive! I’ll eat you!”

I’ll then be a better meal for you. Sit on my stool in the meantime!”
